intro.label: Introduction
intro.text: Dora is a Legal Practice Management SaaS designed and built end-to-end for the Brazilian legal market. The platform orchestrates clients, cases, finance, subscriptions, and AI-assisted workflows with a real-world focus on legal ops.

process.label: Process
steps: The project started with product definition and UX design in Figma, translating legal workflows into task-oriented interfaces that support daily professional use.

intro.label: Introduction
intro.text: Product Designer · Full Stack Developer. A native iOS application designed to help freelancers and creatives manage income and expenses with clarity, speed, and minimal friction. Freelancers often face irregular income and complex financial tracking, yet most finance apps are designed for traditional employees. Existing solutions felt generic, overwhelming, and stressful to use.

process.label: Process
steps: The project began with research and discovery through interviews with freelancers and independent workers, combined with an analysis of existing personal finance apps to identify usability gaps and common pain points.

Based on these insights, wireframes were created with a strong focus on speed and simplicity. The interface was then developed into high-fidelity designs in Figma, aligned with Apple's Human Interface Guidelines, and iterated continuously to remove unnecessary steps.

The application was built using Swift and SwiftUI, with Firebase integrated for authentication and data storage. Core user flows were tested directly on real devices throughout development to ensure reliability and performance.

designDecisions.label: Design Decisions & Outcome
steps: A minimalist interface was prioritized to reduce financial anxiety and improve clarity. Visual summaries replaced dense tables, native iOS patterns were followed to shorten the learning curve, and user flows were designed to require as little manual input as possible.
The result was a polished and functional iOS application. Early feedback highlighted its clarity, ease of use, and the value of simplicity when working with personal finance tools.

intro.label: Introduction
intro.text:
Product Designer · Web Designer. A modern marketing website designed for a logistics and freight company, focused on clarity, credibility, and operational scale. Logistics platforms often struggle to communicate complex services in a simple and trustworthy way. Many existing industry websites feel outdated, overly technical, or visually cluttered, making it difficult for potential clients to quickly understand offerings and value.

The goal of this project was to design a clean, structured, and confident digital presence that communicates reliability, global reach, and operational efficiency, while remaining approachable for new and existing customers.

process.label: Process
steps: The project began with an analysis of logistics and freight industry websites to identify common usability and communication issues, including dense layouts, unclear messaging, and lack of visual trust signals.

Based on these insights, the information architecture was restructured to prioritize clarity and flow. Wireframes were created to define a clear hierarchy between services, company positioning, and calls to action. High-fidelity designs were then developed in Webflow, focusing on clean typography, restrained color usage, and strong visual balance to convey professionalism and scale.

Particular attention was given to responsive behavior, ensuring the site remained clear and readable across devices. The final result is a streamlined, modern logistics website that presents complex services in a clear, confident, and accessible way.

intro.label: Introduction
intro.text: I own the full product lifecycle — from interface design to database architecture to deployment pipelines. Every product I ship goes through the same loop: define the problem, design the solution, write the code, deploy it, and iterate based on real usage. No handoffs. One stack, one owner.

role.label: Role
role.text: Product Designer · iOS Developer · Frontend Engineer

process.label: How I Work
steps: Design starts with structure, not aesthetics. I map out data models, user flows, and edge cases before opening Figma — the same approach whether it's a finance dashboard or a legal case tracker. Components are built as a system, not individual screens, so the design scales with the product. When I move to code, the component library mirrors the design tokens 1:1.

Native iOS work is done in Swift and SwiftUI. I use MVVM with clear boundaries between views, state management, and data layers. Builds go through TestFlight for real-device validation — I don't ship anything that only ran in a simulator.

Web products are built with React and Next.js on TypeScript, styled with Tailwind CSS. I architect for maintainability — small composable components, server-side rendering where it matters, and a clean separation between UI logic and API calls. Backend services run on Supabase or Firebase with PostgreSQL, row-level security, and auth handled at the middleware layer.

AI is embedded in how I build — not bolted on. I use Claude and LLM APIs during architecture decisions, code generation, and debugging. Prompts are part of the workflow the same way tests are: structured, versioned, and intentional. The goal isn't to write less code — it's to ship better products faster.

designDecisions.label: Infrastructure
steps: All source code lives on GitHub with atomic commits and clear PR history. Web projects deploy through Vercel — preview environments on every push, production on merge to main. iOS builds are distributed via TestFlight. When a project requires payments, I integrate Stripe end-to-end: products, subscriptions, webhooks, and entitlements.

Owning design, frontend, backend, and infrastructure removes the gap between intent and execution. What gets designed is what gets built. What gets built is what gets deployed. There's no translation layer where fidelity gets lost.
